item.title: AWP 2 Projects Review

item.description:
The Beyond WTO Program (B-WTO) was developed in response to a request from the Government of Vietnam (GoV) for donor support to help with managing economic integration and the transition to a market economy following WTO accession. The B-WTO goal is âto strengthen governmentâs capacity to manage the integration of Vietnam into the global economy and the transition of Vietnam to a socialist market economyâ. The immediate objective is âimplementation of priority policy actions from the GoVâs Action Plan to enhance Vietnamâs capacity to sustain pro-poor growth (GAP)â.

The remit of this project was a review of the 2nd annual work planâs implementation (AWP2) of Phase 2 of the B-WTO in May 2013. The objectives of the review were to:

  • Evaluate the project implementation performance and project results relative to the logical framework targets and evaluation criteria.
  • Evaluate the results achieved at the Component and Programâs level according to the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) framework of the Program.
  • Identify lessons learned from implementation, make recommendations for the remaining duration of the program and the Independent Completion Report process.

item.title: Health Program M&E
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
In partnership with the Ministry of Health (MoH), the Australian Government is scoping and piloting a new approach to engagement in the health sector in Timor-Leste. The program approach is innovative in several respects. Key program features are: a systems perspective; joint program oversight by MoH and Australian Government; an emphasis on capacity facilitation through coaching rather than an over-reliance on more traditional technical assistance approaches; ongoing processes of joint intervention design throughout implementation; and rapid cycles of evidence-informed adaptation. These will require significant investments in interactive, exploratory, and rigorous monitoring and evaluation, requiring support from an M&E Specialist that is comfortable with non-traditional M&E approaches.

The Health Program M&E Specialist worked with the Australian Government Timor-Leste Health Team to design an M&E system for Australiaâs support to the health sector, that is aligned with the Ministry of Healthâs draft Sector M&E Framework and consistent with Australian Aid Program M&E Standards. The primary purpose of the M&E System will be to support strategic management and ongoing improvement of the Australian Government - MoH partnership in the health sector.

item.title: Program 2013 Performance and Quality Mapping Exercise
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description: AusAIDâs PNG Program is looking to improve its performance and quality (P&Q) standards and systems. The purpose of this project was to map the PNG Programâs current P&Q capacity and systems, to address the risk of AusAID being unable to demonstrate results for its increased investments in PNG over the next four years. Over the last several years, the PNG Program has undertaken a number of M&E assessments and reviews which have identified key strengths and challenges within the program. This project was intended to pick up where these assessments left off. Through a desk review and consultations with sector teams, the Review Team were to distil key P&Q risks and issues for the PNG Program. The Review Teamâs brief included the provision of recommendations on priority activities to support sector approaches to M&E, strengthen the Programâs ability to collect evidence, provide critical analysis and report on results.

item.title: Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
AusAID required a consultant to assist with the development and finalisation of its Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework. Development of a humanitarian monitoring and evaluation framework is a key commitment outlined in AusAIDâs 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy (HAP) and its associated Implementation Plan. In line with the agency focus on results reporting, the HAP and HAP Implementation Plan commit AusAID to develop a monitoring and evaluation framework to support the initial performance assessment framework contained within the HAP and AusAID annual reporting under the Comprehensive Aid Policy Framework.

The key objective of this assignment was to build the Humanitarian programâs capacity for monitoring and reporting results by:

  • In consultation with AusAIDâs Humanitarian team, redraft and finalise the Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework, to ensure it provides a platform to:
  • Track implementation of key commitments in Australiaâs 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy; and,
  • Establish a set of measurable humanitarian performance indicators (in addition to the two CAPF indicators) to enable AusAID to track achievements, lessons learned and to report on the results achieved from AusAIDâs humanitarian work.

item.title: Study on Community-based Social Protection
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
Poverty and Social Analysis is the process of using and generating evidence on poverty throughout the aid management cycle. Most poverty and social analysis focuses on economic and human capital, but there are two oft neglected elements: voice and influence, and social capital. Yet more and more development practitioners are recognizing the importance of social capital, particularly informal social capital, in preventing and addressing poverty and vulnerability.

This project supported AusAID to explore:

  • the role of informal social capital in the Fijian context and whether it lends itself to fair redistribution of resources and, if so, the ways in which AusAID can engage with local communities to strengthen existing social capital structures
  • how such structures can enable the disempowered and poor to claim their entitlements in the three domains discussed in the PSA framework
  • the potential challenges that can arise from such efforts. For instance, the poorest are often included on less favorable terms within social networks, and have access to fewer and lower-quality networks. Further, we need to better understand how poverty and disempowerment intersect with an absence of informal social capital, the repercussions this has, and the options available for tackling this.

item.title: Provision of a Child Protection Specialist
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
For this project HTSPE was contracted to provide a child protection specialist and handle all the associated management and administrative work.

The child protection specialist provided by HTSPE was required to work on an assignment designed to assist the Pacific Division (PACD) to improve its approach to child protection and managing risks to children. AusAID has a number of partners in the Pacific who work with children or come into contact with children through their activities. The AusAID-wide child protection stocktake, conducted in May 2013 found that there are a number of organisations funded by AusAID in the Pacific with a high or very high inherent child protection risk. Consistent with the stocktake report PACD proposes to escalate efforts to ensure partner organisations policies, procedures and practices are in accordance with AusAIDâs Child Protection Policy 2013 and to make child protection a more explicit focus of PACDâs risk management system.
